title: 113_s1183
content: The "Death Tax Repeal Act of 2013" is a bill that aims to repeal estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Death Tax Repeal Act of 2013 terminates the application of estate taxes for decedents dying after its enactment. Additionally, certain distributions from Qualified Domestic Trusts are exempt from specific provisions for surviving spouses of decedents before the Act's enactment. Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax is also repealed under this Act. The Death Tax Repeal Act of 2013 terminates estate taxes for decedents dying after its enactment. Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax is also repealed. Amendments apply to estates and transfers after the Act's enactment date. The Gift Tax is modified by the amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, changing the computation of the tax based on the aggregate sum of taxable gifts for each calendar year and preceding periods. The Gift Tax computation is based on different brackets: 18% for amounts up to $10,000, increasing with higher amounts up to 30% for amounts over $100,000. For amounts over $100,000, the Gift Tax rate is $38,800 plus 32% of the excess over $150,000. For amounts over $250,000, the rate is $70,800 plus 34% of the excess over $250,000. For amounts over $500,000, the rate is $155,800 plus 35% of the excess over $500,000. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces new rules for the treatment of transfers in trust as taxable gifts, unless the trust is considered wholly owned by the donor or the donor's spouse. Additionally, the amendment adjusts the lifetime gift exemption amount under section 2505(a) to $5,000,000. The tax computation is to be adjusted for inflation after 2011, with the dollar amount in subsection (a)(1) increasing annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Rounding rules apply for adjusted amounts that are not multiples of $10,000. The tax computation is adjusted for inflation after 2011, with amounts rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. Conforming amendments are made to section 2505 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to gifts made on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. A transition rule treats the calendar year of enactment as two separate calendar years for tax purposes.
